video.title: Python API Development - Comprehensive Course for Beginners
video.description:
Learn Python API development in one of the most comprehensive courses ever on the topic. You will build a full-fledged API in Python using FastAPI. You will learn the fundamentals of API design including routes, serialization/deserialization, schema validation, and models. You will also learn about SQL, testing with pytest, and how to build out a CI/CD pipeline using GitHub actions.

💻 Code: https://github.com/Sanjeev-Thiyagarajan/fastapi-course

✏️ Course from Sanjeev Thiyagarajan. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC2sYgV-NV6S5_-pqLGChoNQ

Around 12:01:17 I am running into an issue with running alembic on Heroku console. 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/app/.heroku/python/bin/alembic", line 5, in <module>
    from alembic.config import main
  File "/app/.heroku/python/lib/python3.10/site-packages/alembic/config.py", line 15, in <module>
    from . import command
  File "/app/.heroku/python/lib/python3.10/site-packages/alembic/command.py", line 13, in <module>
    from .script import ScriptDirectory
  File "/app/.heroku/python/lib/python3.10/site-packages/alembic/script/__init__.py", line 1, in <module>
    from .base import Script
  File "/app/.heroku/python/lib/python3.10/site-packages/alembic/script/base.py", line 35, in <module>
    from dateutil import tz
  File "/app/.heroku/python/lib/python3.10/site-packages/dateutil/tz.py", line 78
    `self._name`,

This here is an indication that there was a contradiction with a dependency call python-dateutil.
with  python-dateutil==2.8.2 the app would not build.
 python-dateutil==1.5 the app would build. but gives me that error up there where i was able to change it - that is updating the new version of 2.8.2 inside the local tz.py file -locally and it worked there .
However, Heroku only work with version 1.5, my app requires 2.8.2.
I tried the pipenv way where I would set my environment to work with 2.8.2 but heroku still yelled at me for not having the correct version 1.5.

only thing I am trying to find now, is a way to update that dependency " /site-packages/dateutil/tz.py  " in the env that Heroku creates when it is building my app. I went to thier github and found the newer version where they updated this tz.py. I suspect this could be one way to make it work. I just have to find a way to update it inside heroku
Any help  would be very very appreciated.  let me know if what I have done needs to be tweaked, or if I just wasted a week in an infinite loop.

topLevelComment.author: Nihal Athikkai
Debanjan Sarkar
topLevelComment.text:
I want to clarify the issue that is happening at 4:23:45. 
The cursor.execute() method takes an iterable object as its 2nd argument(like list, tuple, string, etc.), because internally the function loops through the values passed in 2nd argument, to place them into the "%s" placeholders of the 1st argument. Now, when we write like this :- (id) or like (2), because of only single value, it is considered as integer, and not a tuple even parenthesis are used. 
But if we just put a comma and make it like this:- (id,) or (2,), it is indicative of multiple values, and now the object is a tuple, which is an iterable.

Here, we actually do not need the string conversion that is being shown here as cursor.execute(...,str(id)), and we can simply do it as cursor.execute(... , (id,)). It is better actually. 

But nevertheless, this content is best in Youtube. Hats off to freecodecamp and Mr. Sanjeev Thiyagarajan sir!

replies.author: jrkave
replies.text: For anyone else encountering this error,  I resolved it after going to my import statement in models.py, changing it to "from database import Base," and then going back to main.py and changing the two import statements to "import models" and "from database import engine, SessionLocal."

topLevelComment.author: raianmr
topLevelComment.text:
I did some digging in the psycopg2 implementation and I think I have an explanation that ties together what you're addressing at 4:21:33 and 4:23:36. 

TLDR: Always use a 'sequence' like tuples, lists, and so on for the second parameter of cursor.execute(). For tuples with a single object, write '(object, )' instead of '(object)'. 

Firstly, we should look at some signatures.

The execute method for cursor objects:
def execute(self, query: str | bytes | Composable, vars: _Vars = ...) -> None: ...

The _Vars type alias:
_Vars: TypeAlias = Sequence[Any] | Mapping[str, Any] | None

These explain what makes the 'convert to str' workaround tick. But as you've demonstrated before while writing the create_posts function, you can pass non-string values (e.g., bools in the case of post.published) just fine. So, why wasn't '(id)' working? I think this is because of the weird syntax of Python's tuples. '(id)' is not necessarily a tuple, and therefore not a sequence either. But '(id, )' is always a tuple in Python, and so it works just fine. But when you're forcing it to be a tuple with that extra comma, your previous workaround of converting to string becomes redundant. And because that workaround doesn't always work, I think it's safe to say that we should try not to write code that way. I hope this helped.

topLevelComment.author: Mosawer Mahboob
topLevelComment.text: At 4:23:35, when the teacher draws our attention to some weird issue, well, let me tell you what the reason is. Simply put, the connection.execute('SQL', (VARIABLES,)) function expects you to pass in the variables in a tuple. In python, you cannot declare a tuple of length one unless you specify it. Two ways to specify that, first is to cast it to the tuple() function, and the other option is to pass in the first item of the tuple and put a single comma (item1,) to indicate a tupple. So, what happens is, when you pass a single item to the tuple and no comma, the () are stripped away and the type of the item gets passed directly.

topLevelComment.author: Oanh Mai
topLevelComment.text:
Last chance to join us at a FREE live hand-on virtual workshop - Intro to oneAPI and to Intel® DevCloud!

https://software.seek.intel.com/oneapi-SYCLprogrammingbasics

oneAPI is a productive, smart path to freedom for accelerated computing delivering a unified programming model for development across diverse architectures. It includes unified and simplified languages and libraries for expressing parallelism delivering uncompromising native high-level language performance across a range of hardware including CPUs, GPUs, FPGAs. If you are a developer with a foundational knowledge of C or C++, FPGA & GPU Programming, this workshop is for you!
In this workshop, Intel Developer Evangelist for AI and oneAPI Praveen Kundurthy will unpack the details, including:
1. Articulate how oneAPI can solve the challenges of programming in a heterogeneous world
2. Understand the SYCL language for High Performance Computing Applications and oneAPI programming model
3. Explain how to use SYCL Buffers and Accessors for data and memory management between host and device
4. Learn the basics of Graphs and Dependences in SYCL
5. Onboard to Intel® DevCloud to test-drive oneAPI tools and libraries
6. Get familiarization on how to use Jupyter notebooks on Intel DevCloud for hands on training through simple SYCL code examples

We look forward to seeing you there.

topLevelComment.author: Oanh Mai
topLevelComment.text:
Last chance to join us at a FREE live hand-on virtual workshop - Advanced SYCL Concepts for Heterogenous Computing!

https://software.seek.intel.com/oneapi-advancedSYCLconcepts

Learn and practice the advanced concepts and features of DPC++ with live sample code on Intel DevCloud. At the end of this workshop, you will be able to efficiently write SYCL code for heterogenous computing. Be one of the first programmers at the forefront of this compelling and important new development that elevates computing to a new level.
In this workshop, Intel Developer Evangelist Rakshith Krishnappa will cover some advanced concepts in SYCL programming for heterogenous computing. Topics include:

- Learn pointer-based memory management for heterogenous computing using Unified Shared Memory.
- Understand implicit and explicit way of moving memory using Unified Shared Memory and also handling data dependency between kernel executions.
- Understand advantages of using Subgroups in SYCL programming.
- Take advantage of Subgroup group algorithms and understand how Subgroup Shuffle operations can avoid explicit memory operations
- Use SYCL reduction to simplify reduction with parallel kernels
- Take advantages reduce function to do reduction at sub_group and work_group level

We look forward to seeing you there.

topLevelComment.author: Coolidge
topLevelComment.text: is there any reason to use sqlalchemy if you're comfortable with SQL?

replies.author: Paulifea
replies.text: SQLAlchemy provides an interface that is ORM (Object Relational Mapping) to translate your code into SQL behind the scenes, while relying the underlying database driver to connect to your database. I doubt it's a matter of choosing between sqlalchemy or SQL. but if you're more comfortable with writing SQL commands, then you can omit using sqlalchemy and send your SQL commands directly to the session/database driver as this tutor has covered in the first half of this video

topLevelComment.author: Elizabeth Daly
topLevelComment.text:
Hi, I've just finished the alembic section (10.30 - 11.13)  and I ran in to more problems with my imports & paths.
To do all the alembic stuff with Sanjeev, I had to stop my uvicorn server and import in the following way:
models.py : from app.database import Base # alembic ok but server error
database.py: from app.config import settings # alembic ok but server error
config.py:  env_file = ".env" # alembic ok but server error

If I leave those lines as above and try to start my uvicorn server, I get a pile of errors to do with imports. 
So, to run the server (when going through the CORS material), I have to change the above lines to:
models.py :  from database import Base # alembic error but server runs
database.py:  from config import settings # alembic gave error but server runs
config.py: env_file = "../.env" # for server ok but alembic error

Searching around I can find some reference to this type of error. I **think** it might have to do with the line
prepend_sys_path = . in the alembic.ini file that is run when doing alembic init
https://github.com/sqlalchemy/alembic/issues/797

Has anyone come across this? For now, I'm hacking my way along, editing files as need be, but I imagine I'll run into problems when I try to host.

replies.author: Elizabeth Daly
replies.text:
I know that probably nobody cares except me, but I finally, finally, finally figured out the stupid relative imports problem I described above. I had to do all my imports as relative ones when I was deploying my app on Heroku (same lines of code as in relevant files in Sanjeev's github repo). And everything, including "alembic upgrade head" works beautifully.  I have the exact same directory structure as Sanjeev, so main.py lives in the fastapi\app directory.

However, as expected, it falls apart when I tried to run my uvicorn server on my local machine

C:\Users\lizma\fastapi\app (main -> origin)
(venv1) λ uvicorn main:app

I print out some messages at the start of main.py to help me figure out what's going on. These are:
Dir of current script C:\Users\lizma\fastapi\app\.
the package is
the name is main

And I get this error 
ImportError: attempted relative import with no known parent package
at the very first relative import. Python does not appear to know what the package is, hence the blank above

****
The solution I found is to go up a level and run the file as a module like this:
C:\Users\lizma\fastapi (main -> origin)
(venv1) λ uvicorn app.main:app
Dir of current script C:\Users\lizma\fastapi\.\app
the package is app
the name is app.main

So now Python appears to know that the app directory is actually a package and is able to figure out all the relative imports. Woo hoo.

This answer was helpful: https://stackoverflow.com/a/65589847

topLevelComment.author: itarukmakto
topLevelComment.text:
7:37:00  The JWT token did not expire at all for me regardless of the time value I set. It appears there is no automatic check for expiry time going on. I could make it work by doing the following:

1. Moved the verify_token code block inside get_current_user.
2. Retrieved also the "expire" value from decoded token. If value is none, raise exception. If available then compare it with current time. If current time is greater than the expiry time then it means token is expired , so raise exception. Code block here:

expire = payload.get("expire")
    if expire is None:
        raise credentials_exception
       
    if datetime.now() > datetime.fromtimestamp(expire) :
        raise credentials_exception


Note: I used "datetime.fromtimestamp(expires)" instead of expires directly because earlier in create_access_token, the "expire" value was converted to expire.timestamp() before it was appended/updated to the "to_encode" variable. This was done to fix error "TypeError: Object of type datetime is not JSON serializable"

topLevelComment.text: Absolute bomber content, thank you Sanjeev, youre the best! For those that get an update error after  5:28:00 of a kind: sqlalchemy.exc.IntegrityError: (psycopg2.errors.NotNullViolation) null value in column "id" of relation "posts" violates not-null constraint. For me the problem was that the pydantic Post class had id: Optional[int] which would not be submitted and becomes null in the updated_post, and you cant update id`s with null. My fix was to remove id and created_at from Post class, i think he will do it later himself anyway.

topLevelComment.author: shashank chauhan
topLevelComment.text:
At ( 4:21:58 ) : We don't need to explicitly convert the (id) to a string , which is being passed as an argument . The cur.execute() method takes two arguments - 1. A string, which is a SQL query . 2. A tuple, which contains the variables we want to pass into that query. So, in Python we define a tuple with a single element as --> ( id , )  not ( id ) . Here ( id ) is just an integer not a tuple .
Conclusion : Use this instead --> cur.execute( " " "  SELECT * FROM posts WHERE id = %s " " " , ( id , ) )  .This should work fine .

replies.author: Siddhartha Puligilla
replies.text:
I did this by adding the following logic at the top of create_user function:

    email = user.email
    exists = db.query(models.User).filter(models.User.email ==  email).first()
    
    if exists:
        raise HTTPException(status_code=status.HTTP_409_CONFLICT, 
                            detail=f'email address {email} is taken, try a different one')

It works but I am a bit iffy on the 409 status code, you may want to lookup whether that's the correct code for record conflicts.

Fantastic course, thanks. I'm at 6:26 just after he creates the routers folder containing post.py and user.py I'm running into a problem with all the relative imports. Well, I ran into it before now but I hacked my way around it. Now, with creation of the app/routers folders, I can't avoid relative imports so I am getting this error if I leave the code as in video

File "C:\Users\lizma\fastapi\app\.\main.py", line 20, in <module>

ImportError: attempted relative import with no known parent package

Every relative import will result in an error like that. Been looking around on stackoverflow and there is a lot of content on relative imports, but I'm hoping for an easy answer :). @Aljaž Klemenčič  
Hi, I resolved it by avoiding all the dots ... / relative imports
So in main.py I have:
import models, schemas, utils
from database import engine, get_db
from routers import post, user

and in the post.py and user.py files I use:
import models, schemas
from database import get_db

Spent ages on stackoverflow and somewhere, can't remember where, I read that if you run a script in a dir that contains __init__.py file, that dir is not regarded as a package as it is not in the sys.path Anyway, all my requests are working in Postman with code as above. topLevelComment.author: Ammar
topLevelComment.text:
Issue at 10:26:00
The issue seems to lie in inheriting from PostBase (or Post for that matter) from schemas. The issue is fixed when PostOut inherits from BaseModel instead. 
As the response (without response model) returns a Post dictionary and a vote count, it does not have the fields that PostBase requires (title and content are present in the Post dictionary within the response, not within the response directly like vote count). PostBase (or Post) can be used if a new dictionary is defined that includes all the fields that PostBase (or Post) requires.
Also orm_mode need not be set in PostOut as it uses the class Post that has orm_mode set (this is used to import owner information and show it as a dictionary despite it being an object).
Also the fields defined in PostOut must match what the query returns (which can be seen by removing the response model), which is why the field 'Post' must have a capital P (as the model.py contains Post) and why the label for vote count in the query must be the same as the respective field defined in PostOut.

topLevelComment.author: KillerFridge
topLevelComment.text:
Ok, error fixer KillerFridge is back - the issue you had at 10:25:43 is that originally you built the new schema as PostOut(PostBase) (inheriting from PostBase) not PostOut(BaseModel) (inheriting from BaseModel):

Because PostOut(PostBase) is inheriting from "PostBase" is still expecting to find the "title", "content" etc. fields, which you aren't providing, you have just extended it adding an additional field "Post". When we come back at 10:25.43, you have changed it to inherit "BaseModel" which isn't expecting those fields and so works fine - nothing to do with the capitalisation.

replies.author: Mark
replies.text:
To add some context to your comment, the indexing issue is because he is trying to pass a tuple with a single value. Tuples with a single value requires a comma after the value. With out the comma, python doesn't recognize it as a tuple, and that's creating the error. From the Psycopg docs: "For positional variables binding, the second argument must always be a sequence, even if it contains a single variable (remember that Python requires a comma to create a single element tuple):" 

Apparently Psycopg is cool with using a list instead of tuple. IIRC, the SQLite3 module in Python requires that positional variables be a tuple.

Also, as you mentioned, all he needed to do was (id,). It's not necessary to convert the id to a string as psycopg handles converting whatever input it is given to a string. It's all in the docs here: https://www.psycopg.org/docs/usage.html#passing-parameters-to-sql-queries

Guys, if you are interested in how you can validate the dir type for your pydantic Vote model. 

It's as simple as creating an enum

----------------------------------------
eg:

from enum import Enum

class VoteType(int, Enum):
     UP = 1
     DOWN = 0

class Vote(BaseModel):
     post_id: int
     dir: VoteType
----------------------------------------

if anyone has a better solution, please share your solution.

topLevelComment.text: The issue around 4:23:53 (and actually I also believe the issue around why it's not accepting an int) is because the cursor.execute() function expects a Tuple as the second argument. Without the comma the parenthesis are meaningless. cursor.execute("""SELECT * FROM posts WHERE id=%s""", (id,)) works just fine

replies.author: Christopher Grubb
replies.text: @James Reader Right. vars needs to be indexable, so (id,) or [id] is best. Converting id into a string only works when using a single digit id. If you try with id=10, then it would take the first index (which is '10'[0], so '1') for the first %s, but not know what to do with the second index (which is '10'[1] , so '0'). So you would get a TypeError, since not all arguments '1' and '0' would be able to be converted during string formatting.

replies.author: James Reader
replies.text: Close, but not quite accurate.  It's because it's expecting an indexable object.  an int isn't indexable .  A tuple is, so that works, so does an array [id]  or even {id} as well as the tuple (id,)

At 9:37 you ask how to enforce 0 or 1 in Pydantic but in my mind this is the perfect opportunity to use a Boolean.

So schema will look something like this... 

class Vote(BaseModel):
  post_id: int
  voted: bool

Then the check is simply 

if vote.voted:

replies.author: James Reader

topLevelComment.author: Derick Jansen
topLevelComment.text: At 4:24:00  you wonder why you need the extra comma this is because the second argument has to be a sequence (iterable) . A quirk of python is that (id) is not a tuple. To create a tuple you have to do (id,) else it sees it as an int.  Interesting thing is, because it expects an iterable you can use a list  like this ("""SELECT * FROM posts WHERE id=%s""", [id]).fetchone().

replies.author: Derick Jansen
replies.text: And also this ("""INSERT INTO posts (title, content, published) VALUES (%s, %s, %s) RETURNING *""",  [post.title, post.content, post.published])

topLevelComment.author: rainwave5
topLevelComment.text:
04:23:45 for anyone curious whenever you pass in arguments into a cursor for a db as such you always wants to turn the information into a tuple. So as Sanjeev mentioned you can just use 
(value,) # this is assuming its a single value
or 
(value1, value2) or (value1, value2,)
09:38:15 So I believe here you could just place bool as the type validation because then if then send 0 it should transform to false or if they do 1 then it should transform to true and vice-versa. So whichever value you wanted can be taken from it.
10:26:10 This error is kind of interesting and I got it as well. I think the best way to go about troubleshooting is to understand that pydantic is going to an error when it isn't provided with sufficient  data as opposed to being provided with too much. After all the response model is meant to cut down the data that is shown to the client. So with this in mind for my schema I made it inherit it from the base model (our imported class) rather than from one of created schema. I think stacking too many schemas put's double the requirements specifically  for the title and content field. One good method to debug this is by inserting in default values into the fields that are causing validation errors as this will create a trail leading you to the issue.
~ 10:15:26 - 10:28:21  more or less here when you group on a column and return columns that are not in the group by nor  being aggregated by a function such as SUM() then you will get an error from SQL. Although I'm not sure why Postgresql didn't return an error. While I was using MS-SQL Server I just did a windowing analytic function such as ...
func.count(models.<insert your orm model>.<insert your column>).over(partition_by=models.<insert your orm model>.<insert your column(group by column)>)).label("<quoi qu'il soit>")

https://vitux.com/how-to-edit-config-files-in-ubuntu/
a good website if you had some issues using vi in ubuntu

12:59:16  if you have problems with your virtual environment where gunicorn isnt in the bin directory then you can use this instead  after installing the library python3 -m venv.

~13:50:00 Around here more or less is where I was having issues connecting to postgres in the container . So What I did was just follow a similar process to what we did for the Ubuntu droplet on digital ocean. So i went into pg_hba and changed some of those settings to md5 and then to be safe in postgres.conf I enabled "*" for the local connections.
Also I had to start the container with the image and then run alembic. Then do docker-compose down and then start it up again.

14:05:00 Here I hadn't been able to log in from the command line nor push any image from docker desktop. So it turns out you can just slightly modify a file in /.docker/config.json just change credsStore to credStore. I'm also using WSL2.

15:10:00 if you start getting errors during the pytests with the traceback involving pydantic you made need this "../.env".
edit: actually it turns out the .env file needs to be in the cwd so that can be for if you decide to enter into a different directory.

15:44:00 😅 setting up alembic to do this looks to be way harder than he makes it seem. I reccommend either swapping the sqlalchemy.url in your env.py or just creating a seperate alembic init for the test db

Amazing tutorial! Loving it so far!

Quick ques: is anyone else having issues with setting up SQLAlchemy with python 3.10 and psycopg? The venv I created was using 3.10 and I just went with it. Later, I realized psycopg2 is supported till py3.9... So I had to install psycopg and work around that but now with SQLAlchemy, it looks like some of the packages inside sqlalchemy are using psycopg2 as a dependency and I don't have it :( 
Any help/guidance is appreciated...

replies.author: Danish Akhtar

replies.author: Ronald Maffei de Lavor
replies.text:
CORAÇÃO DE SÃO JOSÉ

ORIGEM DESTA DEVOÇÃO
Um sacerdote italiano escreveu para o diretor de uma revista de espiritualidade, pedindo para que se divulgasse a devoção ao Coração de São José.

Esta devoção teria sido revelada pelo próprio São José a um religioso de clausura da cidade de Palermo.

Entre outras coisas, escreve: Há dois anos, em 1977, no dia 7 de junho, Festa do Coração Imaculado de Maria, esta pessoa estava rezando o Santo Terço, quando teve uma visão. Viu um sol fulgidíssimo emanando luz branca e no centro um coração de carne, do qual saíam três lírios brancos. O vidente pensou que fosse o Coração de Maria Santíssima; porém, o seu anjo da guarda disse-lhe: Este é o coração do glorioso São José, esposo de Maria Santíssima, que não é conhecido, nem amado pelos cristãos, mas que o Senhor deseja que seja conhecido, amado e honrado, ao lado dos corações de Jesus e Maria.

O anjo continuou dizendo que a Festa do Coração de São José deve ser no domingo após a festa dos Corações de Jesus e Maria, e que todos aqueles que por três domingos consecutivos, em qualquer período do ano comungarem, receberem a Sagrada Eucaristia, em honra do Coração de São José, receberão dele grandes graças e que, qual pai amoroso, sustentará suas almas em todas suas necessidades, e os consolará na hora da morte e será seu advogado ante o tribunal de Deus.

Em outras ocasiões, São José ditou, para o vidente, as Ladainhas do seu Coração e outras orações.

ORAÇÃO AO CORAÇÃO DE SÃO JOSÉ
Ó coração clementíssimo e puríssimo de São José, que palpitastes de amor por Jesus e Maria, voltai-vos para mim, pobre pecador, e alcançai-me a graça que espero (indicar a graça). Ó coração humílimo e paciente, plasmai meu coração conforme o vosso, vós que sempre dissestes sim a Deus. Recordai-vos, ó coração pronto à escuta dos miseráveis e sofredores que, ninguém se dirigiu a vós sem ser ouvido.

Eia, pois, consolai-me e, como confortastes e ajudastes Jesus e Maria, consolai meu pobre coração, para que possa louvar-vos no céu e tornar conhecido na terra, o poder, a riqueza e a bondade do vosso amabilíssimo coração.

SALVE, Ó SÃO JOSÉ
Salve, ó São José, casto esposo de Maria, conforto e esperança nossa, salve! A vós recorremos, pobres pecadores, confiantes em vosso puríssimo coração, a vós suspiramos, consolador dos aflitos, nesta terra de aflição. Eia, pois, nosso advogado e protetor, os vossos olhos piedosos a nós volvei e, depois desta vida, mostrai-nos Jesus a Maria, palpitação de amor do vosso coração. Ó clementíssimo, justo e piedoso custódio de Deus.

Coração puríssimo de São José, confio que tudo podeis junto ao Coração de Jesus.

LADAINHA AO CORAÇÃO DE SÃO JOSÉ
Senhor, tende piedade de nós.

Jesus Cristo, tende piedade de nós.

Senhor, tende piedade de nós.

Jesus Cristo, ouvi-nos.

Jesus Cristo, atendei-nos.

Deus Pai do céu que sois Deus, tende piedade de nós.

Deus Filho, redentor do mundo, que sois Deus. Tende piedade de nós.

Deus Espírito Santo, que sois Deus, tende piedade de nós.

Santíssima Trindade, que sois um só Deus, tende piedade de nós.

Santa Maria, rogai por nós.

Coração de São José, custódio de Jesus e Maria, rogai por nós.

Coração de São José, obedientíssimo ao Pai, rogai por nós.

Coração de São José, justíssimo, rogai por nós.

Coração de São José, clementíssimo, rogai por nós.

Coração de São José, pacientíssimo, rogai por nós.

Coração de São José, puríssimo de corpo, mente e intenção, rogai por nós.

Fonte:
https://quemrezasesalva.com.br/devocao/coracao-de-sao-jose
